htmlEmbed:
AI took their jobs. Now they get paid to make it sound humanThomas Germain6/16/2024

If you're worried about how AI will affect your job, the world of copywriters may offer a glimpse of the future.

Read

dKljgB"><h1 class="sc-518485e5-0 bWszMR">AI took their jobs. Now they get paid to make it sound human<!-- --></h1></div><div data-component="byline-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><div data-testid="byline" class="sc-1d2e900b-0 fhxEhT"><div class="sc-1d2e900b-1 gwgaEc"><div class="sc-1d2e900b-9 eMfYfM"><time class="sc-1d2e900b-10 WPunI">16 June 2024</time></div><div class="sc-1d2e900b-2 bDFePy"><div class="sc-1d2e900b-3 dSEqup"><span data-testid="byline-name" class="sc-1d2e900b-6 hhBctz">By<!-- -->Thomas Germain<!-- -->,<!-- --></span></div></div></div><div class="sc-1d2e900b-11 fPUyIi"><div data-testid="popoverWrapper" data-component="image-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 loyNYl"><div data-testid="hero-image" class="sc-13b8515c-1 bbjeKz"><img src="/bbcx/grey-placeholder.png" class="sc-13b8515c-0 WTpgI hide-when-no-script"/><img sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" srcSet="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 160w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 240w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 320w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 480w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 640w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 800w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 1024w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 1376w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp 1920w" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vksd.jpg.webp" loading="eager" alt="Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images Hands typing on a typewriter (Credit: Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)" class="sc-13b8515c-0 hbOWRP"/><span class="sc-13b8515c-2 iuvLSH">Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images</span></div></div><div data-component="caption-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 khQhed"><figcaption class="sc-8353772e-0 cvNhQw">(Credit: Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)<!-- --></figcaption></div></figure><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe"><b id="if-you're-worried-about-how-ai-will-affect-your-job,-the-world-of-copywriters-may-offer-a-glimpse-of-the-future." class="sc-7dcfb11b-0 kVRnKf">If you're worried about how AI will affect your job, the world of copywriters may offer a glimpse of the future.<!-- --></b></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Writer Benjamin Miller  not his real name  was thriving in early 2023. He led a team of more than 60 writers and editors, publishing blog posts and articles to promote a tech company that packages and resells data on everything from real estate to used cars. "It was really engaging work," Miller says, a chance to flex his creativity and collaborate with experts on a variety of subjects. But one day, Miller's manager told him about a new project. "They wanted to use AI to cut down on costs," he says. (Miller signed a non-disclosure agreement, and asked the BBC to withhold his and the company's name.)<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">A month later, the business introduced an automated system. Miller's manager would plug a headline for an article into an online form, an AI model would generate an outline based on that title, and Miller would get an alert on his computer. Instead of coming up with their own ideas, his writers would create articles around those outlines, and Miller would do a final edit before the stories were published. Miller only had a few months to adapt before he got news of a second layer of automation. Going forward, ChatGPT would write the articles in their entirety, and most of his team was fired. The few people remaining were left with an even less creative task: editing ChatGPT's subpar text to make it sound more human.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">By 2024, the company laid off the rest of Miller's team, and he was alone. "All of a sudden I was just doing everyone's job," Miller says. Every day, he'd open the AI-written documents to fix the robot's formulaic mistakes, churning out the work that used to employ dozens of people.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="quote-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><div class="sc-9967660-0 WkJHg"><div class="sc-9967660-1 dBFvZy"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" width="1em" height="1em" category="personalisation" icon="quote" class="sc-1097f7fe-0 jmthjj"><path d="M9.83967 17.2131C9.205 17.2131 8.62967 17.3124 8.07567 17.5058C8.63767 13.3384 10.9143 10.0091 14.7517 6.88708H10.0903C6.281 10.2704 4.00033 14.6318 4.00033 20.0451C4.00033 24.4311 6.35567 26.9371 9.78967 26.9371C13.0223 26.9371 14.9023 24.5564 14.9023 21.9751C14.9023 19.2184 12.7217 17.2131 9.83967 17.2131Z"></path><path d="M22.2957 17.2131C21.6611 17.2131 21.0864 17.3124 20.5317 17.5058C21.0931 13.3384 23.3704 10.0091 27.2077 6.88708H22.5464C18.7371 10.2704 16.4811 14.6318 16.4811 20.0451C16.4811 24.4311 18.8117 26.9371 22.2457 26.9371C25.4784 26.9371 27.3584 24.5564 27.3584 21.9751C27.3584 19.2184 25.1777 17.2131 22.2957 17.2131Z"></path></svg></div><span class="sc-9967660-2 bBAxiJ">In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind</span></div></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_1" id="dotcom-mid_1" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"Mostly, it was just about cleaning things up and making the writing sound less awkward, cutting out weirdly formal or over-enthusiastic language," Miller says. "It was more editing than I had to do with human writers, but it was always the exact same kinds of edits. The real problem was it was just so repetitive and boring. It started to feel like I was the robot."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Miller's experience reflects a broader shift. In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind. AI is often less expensive than a person, but early adopters are quick to learn it can't always perform on the same level. Now, people like Miller are finding themselves being asked to team up with the same robots that are stealing their jobs to give the algorithms a bit of humanity  a hidden army making AI seem better than it really is.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">If AI gets dramatically more effective, this will be a temporary solution. If it doesn't, Miller's story could be a preview of what's coming to other professions.<!-- --></p></div><figure><div data-component="image-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 dOZXmm"><div data-testid="image" class="sc-13b8515c-1 bbjeKz"><img src="/bbcx/grey-placeholder.png" class="sc-13b8515c-0 WTpgI hide-when-no-script"/><img sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" srcSet="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 160w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 240w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 320w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 480w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 640w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 800w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 1024w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 1376w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp 1920w" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vkzg.jpg.webp" loading="lazy" alt="Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images Copywriters are at the forefront of a new line of work: human-AI collaboration (Credit: Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)" class="sc-13b8515c-0 hbOWRP"/><span class="sc-13b8515c-2 iuvLSH">Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images</span></div></div><div data-component="caption-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 khQhed"><figcaption class="sc-8353772e-0 cvNhQw">Copywriters are at the forefront of a new line of work: human-AI collaboration (Credit: Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)<!-- --></figcaption></div></figure><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Will AI steal your job? It's hard to say. We're at an unsettling crossroads, where <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-65746524" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">some experts warn<!-- --></a> that super intelligent robots will soon replace most human work, while <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/worklife/article/20230507-the-jobs-ai-wont-take-yet" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">others believe the technology may never even approach that point<!-- --></a>. There are also some who argue we are heading towards a future of <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://arxiv.org/html/2404.00029v1" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">AI and human collaboration<!-- --></a> rather than competition.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_2" id="dotcom-mid_2" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">But on a much smaller scale, some workers already face distressing consequences. If there's one thing the large language models powered by generative AI can do, it's string together words and paragraphs, putting some writers on the frontline.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">The fear of losing work to AI-powered writing tools was one of the main issues that led to the <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/business-66289583" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">screen writers strike in the US last year<!-- --></a>. And other <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-68384657" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">creative industries face similar concerns<!-- --></a> about their future with the arrival of AI tools capable of generating images, <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-68717863" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">audio<!-- --></a> and video from scratch.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="quote-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><div class="sc-9967660-0 WkJHg"><div class="sc-9967660-1 dBFvZy"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" width="1em" height="1em" category="personalisation" icon="quote" class="sc-1097f7fe-0 jmthjj"><path d="M9.83967 17.2131C9.205 17.2131 8.62967 17.3124 8.07567 17.5058C8.63767 13.3384 10.9143 10.0091 14.7517 6.88708H10.0903C6.281 10.2704 4.00033 14.6318 4.00033 20.0451C4.00033 24.4311 6.35567 26.9371 9.78967 26.9371C13.0223 26.9371 14.9023 24.5564 14.9023 21.9751C14.9023 19.2184 12.7217 17.2131 9.83967 17.2131Z"></path><path d="M22.2957 17.2131C21.6611 17.2131 21.0864 17.3124 20.5317 17.5058C21.0931 13.3384 23.3704 10.0091 27.2077 6.88708H22.5464C18.7371 10.2704 16.4811 14.6318 16.4811 20.0451C16.4811 24.4311 18.8117 26.9371 22.2457 26.9371C25.4784 26.9371 27.3584 24.5564 27.3584 21.9751C27.3584 19.2184 25.1777 17.2131 22.2957 17.2131Z"></path></svg></div><span class="sc-9967660-2 bBAxiJ">We're adding the 'human touch', but that often requires a deep, developmental edit on a piece of writing  Catrina Cowart</span></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">The impact is already being felt among copywriters  the people who write marketing material and other content for businesses. In some corners of the copywriting business, AI is a blessing. <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-65855333" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">It can be a useful tool<!-- --></a> that speeds up work and enhances creativity. But other copywriters, especially those early in their careers, say <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/jan/24/chatgpt-artificial-intelligence-jobs-economy" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">AI is making it harder to find jobs<!-- --></a>.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">But some have also noticed a new type of gig is emerging, one that pays a lot less: fixing the robots' shoddy writing.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_3" id="dotcom-mid_3" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"We're adding the human touch, but that often requires a deep, developmental edit on a piece of writing," says Catrina Cowart, a copywriter based in Lexington, Kentucky, US, who's done work editing AI text."The grammar and word choice just sound weird. You're always cutting out flowery words like 'therefore' and 'nevertheless' that don't fit in casual writing. Plus, you have to fact-check the whole thing because AI just makes things up, which takes forever because it's not just big ideas. AI hallucinates these flippant little things in throwaway lines that you'd never notice."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Cowart says the AI-humanising often takes longer than writing a piece from scratch, but the pay is worse. "On the job platforms where you find this work, it usually maxes out around 10 cents (0.08) a word. But that's when you're writing, This is considered an editing job, so typically you're only getting one to five cents (0.008-0.04) a word," she says.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"It's tedious, horrible work, and they pay you next to nothing for it," Cowart says.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Other industries have seen similar examples of<!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://gizmodo.com/modern-mechanical-turks-automation-humans-in-disguise-1851382957/" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">lower-paid human beings quietly powering the machines<!-- --></a>, from stepping in to help with automated ordering systems to labelling the images used to train AI vision systems in the first place.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="quote-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><div class="sc-9967660-0 WkJHg"><div class="sc-9967660-1 dBFvZy"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" width="1em" height="1em" category="personalisation" icon="quote" class="sc-1097f7fe-0 jmthjj"><path d="M9.83967 17.2131C9.205 17.2131 8.62967 17.3124 8.07567 17.5058C8.63767 13.3384 10.9143 10.0091 14.7517 6.88708H10.0903C6.281 10.2704 4.00033 14.6318 4.00033 20.0451C4.00033 24.4311 6.35567 26.9371 9.78967 26.9371C13.0223 26.9371 14.9023 24.5564 14.9023 21.9751C14.9023 19.2184 12.7217 17.2131 9.83967 17.2131Z"></path><path d="M22.2957 17.2131C21.6611 17.2131 21.0864 17.3124 20.5317 17.5058C21.0931 13.3384 23.3704 10.0091 27.2077 6.88708H22.5464C18.7371 10.2704 16.4811 14.6318 16.4811 20.0451C16.4811 24.4311 18.8117 26.9371 22.2457 26.9371C25.4784 26.9371 27.3584 24.5564 27.3584 21.9751C27.3584 19.2184 25.1777 17.2131 22.2957 17.2131Z"></path></svg></div><span class="sc-9967660-2 bBAxiJ">It's been an incredible co-creative partner  Rebecca Dugas</span></div></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_4" id="dotcom-mid_4" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">But for some in the copywriting world, whether the arrival of AI is a good or bad thing depends on how people approach it, and how far along people are in their careers. Some writers say working the tools into their creative process can even improve their work.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">The <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://www.awai.com/" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">American Writers and Artists Institute<!-- --></a> (AWAI), an organisation that offers training and resources for freelance writers, hosts a variety of courses on artificial intelligence for its members. AWAI president Rebecca Matter says AI classes are now the institute's most popular offering by far. "It's an incredible tool," Matter says. "For people who make copywriting a career, the risk isn't AI taking their jobs, it's that they have to adapt. That can be uncomfortable, but I think it's a huge opportunity."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Matter says the transition to the AI world has been smooth for most of the writers she knows. In fact, it's become such an inherent part of the copywriting process that many writers now add personal "AI policies" to their professional websites to explain how they use the technology.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Rebecca Dugas, a copywriter with nine years of experience, says AI has been a "godsend" that lets her turn out the same high-quality work in a fraction of the time.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"I use AI whenever my clients are comfortable with it," she says. "Whether it's brainstorming, market research, reworking paragraphs when I'm banging my head against the wall, it's been an incredible co-creative partner."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_5" id="dotcom-mid_5" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><figure><div data-component="image-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 dOZXmm"><div data-testid="image" class="sc-13b8515c-1 bbjeKz"><img src="/bbcx/grey-placeholder.png" class="sc-13b8515c-0 WTpgI hide-when-no-script"/><img sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" srcSet="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 160w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 240w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 320w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 480w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 640w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 800w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 1024w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 1376w,https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp 1920w" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0j3vlzk.jpg.webp" loading="lazy" alt="AI makes life easier for some writers, but for others, it adds insult to injury (Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)" class="sc-13b8515c-0 hbOWRP"/></div></div><div data-component="caption-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 khQhed"><figcaption class="sc-8353772e-0 cvNhQw">AI makes life easier for some writers, but for others, it adds insult to injury (Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)<!-- --></figcaption></div></figure><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">But Dugas understands that clients may have reservations about the technology. <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://heartsellcopy.com/2023/12/generative-ai-helps-writers-write/" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">Her own AI policy<!-- --></a> explains that Dugas is happy to forgo AI for those who prefer it  but you can expect to pay more. The extra time and mental energy required means her AI-free projects come with a higher price tag.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">As AI gets better, Dugas expects that some businesses will turn to ChatGPT and other tools for their writing needs instead of hiring human beings. "But I think even now we're getting to the point where companies are realising that if you don't understand copywriting, you can't judge the effectiveness of what the AI produces," she says. According to Dugas, that means there will always be well-paying work for talented, established writers.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="quote-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><div class="sc-9967660-0 WkJHg"><div class="sc-9967660-1 dBFvZy"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" width="1em" height="1em" category="personalisation" icon="quote" class="sc-1097f7fe-0 jmthjj"><path d="M9.83967 17.2131C9.205 17.2131 8.62967 17.3124 8.07567 17.5058C8.63767 13.3384 10.9143 10.0091 14.7517 6.88708H10.0903C6.281 10.2704 4.00033 14.6318 4.00033 20.0451C4.00033 24.4311 6.35567 26.9371 9.78967 26.9371C13.0223 26.9371 14.9023 24.5564 14.9023 21.9751C14.9023 19.2184 12.7217 17.2131 9.83967 17.2131Z"></path><path d="M22.2957 17.2131C21.6611 17.2131 21.0864 17.3124 20.5317 17.5058C21.0931 13.3384 23.3704 10.0091 27.2077 6.88708H22.5464C18.7371 10.2704 16.4811 14.6318 16.4811 20.0451C16.4811 24.4311 18.8117 26.9371 22.2457 26.9371C25.4784 26.9371 27.3584 24.5564 27.3584 21.9751C27.3584 19.2184 25.1777 17.2131 22.2957 17.2131Z"></path></svg></div><span class="sc-9967660-2 bBAxiJ">Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptly</span></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">But copywriters on the lower end of the career spectrum may not be so lucky. Today, many in that position find themselves in the middle of a distinctly modern set of contradictions.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_6" id="dotcom-mid_6" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">A great deal of copywriting work comes from website owners who want articles that will generate more traffic from Google. However, Google made a number of dramatic announcements in the last year about its <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20240524-how-googles-new-algorithm-will-shape-your-internet" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">effort to remove "unhelpful" content from search results<!-- --></a>. That sparked fears that the tech giant may penalise websites that host AI-generated content. Google maintains that AI-writing is fine if the content is high quality, but these reassurances haven't dissuaded concerns.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">As a result, it's become a common practice in some parts of the copywriting world to run text through AI detection software. Over the last year, <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://gizmodo.com/ai-detectors-inaccurate-freelance-writers-fired-1851529820" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">a wave of writers even say they've lost jobs over false accusations from AI detectors<!-- --></a>.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">According to Cowart, many of the same freelance writing platforms that have AI detection software in place are simultaneously hiring people to edit content produced by chatbots. That means in some corners of the copywriting ecosystem, almost everything revolves around efforts to avoid the appearance of artificial intelligence.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"They're selling AI content and paying you to fix it, and at the same time they're sending you emails about how to write like a human so you don't trigger their AI detector," Cowart says. "It's so insulting." Worse, the detectors are regularly updated to keep up with ongoing changes from the companies who make AI chatbots, which means the rules about what might get your writing flagged as AI constantly shift. "It's frustrating, because there are a million ways to say the same thing in English, but which one is more human? I don't like the guessing," she says.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptly. After months of repetitive editing work, He got called in to an unexpected meeting. On 5 April 2024, the same day a <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-68744372" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">historic earthquake shook his hometown of New York<!-- --></a>, he was laid off. The company decided that Miller was just another unnecessary layer of human intervention.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_7" id="dotcom-mid_7" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">"I more or less got automated out of a job," Miller says.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe"><b id="you-might-also-like:" class="sc-7dcfb11b-0 kVRnKf">You might also like:<!-- --></b></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe"> <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20240515-ai-wisdom-what-happens-when-you-ask-an-algorithm-for-relationship-advice" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">This is what happens when you ask an algorithm for relationship advice<!-- --></a></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe"> <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20240501-how-ai-is-testing-the-boundaries-of-human-intelligence" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">How AI is testing the boundaries of human intelligence<!-- --></a></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe"> <!-- --><a target="_self" href="https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20230224-the-ai-emotions-dreamed-up-by-chatgpt" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">The chatbots that say they can feel emotions<!-- --></a></p></div><div data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit" class="sc-c361b622-0 fHxdon"><div data-testid="dotcom-mid_8" id="dotcom-mid_8" class="dotcom-ad"></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Fortunately, it wasn't long before Miller found a new, if rather ironic, opportunity. He got a job at <!-- --><a target="_blank" href="https://undetectable.ai/" class="sc-c9299ecf-0 bZUiKB">Undetectable AI<!-- --></a>, a technology company that builds software to make AI writing harder to identify. In other words, Miller is helping a company that's using AI to do the work he was forced into <!-- --><i id="after" class="sc-7dcfb11b-0 kKcaog">after <!-- --></i>AI took his job in the first place.<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Bars Juhasz, chief technology officer of Undetectable AI, says tools like the ones his company produces are certain to have some negative effects on the labour market, but he's optimistic about the future of work. "When the automobile was first introduced in an era of horses and carts, people reacted like this was the end of days. But society always adapts," Juhasz says. "I think we're going to see a lot of jobs being replaced, and freelancers will be the hardest hit. I do feel for them. But these people who are getting paid to humanise AI are fantastic opportunists. Sure, it's not a great job, but they have effectively recognised a new seat at a moment when we're redefining the idea of productivity. People who can learn to work with the technology are going to be OK."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">Miller doesn't look back fondly on his time in the AI-humanisation mines. "I contributed to a lot of the garbage that's filling the internet and destroying it," he says. "Nobody was even reading this stuff by the time I left because it's just trash." Ultimately, Miller assumes the company will just take down the AI articles he worked on. "It'll be like it never even happened."<!-- --></p></div><div data-component="text-block" class="sc-43e6b7ba-0 bWSguZ"><p class="sc-eb7bd5f6-0 fYAfXe">--<!-- --></p></div><div He led a team of more than 60 writers and editors, publishing blog posts and articles to promote a tech company that packages and resells data on everything from real estate to used cars. \"It was really engaging work,\" Miller says, a chance to flex his creativity and collaborate with experts on a variety of subjects. But one day, Miller's manager told him about a new project. \"They wanted to use AI to cut down on costs,\" he says. (Miller signed a non-disclosure agreement, and asked the BBC to withhold his and the company's name.)","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Writer Benjamin Miller  not his real name  was thriving in early 2023. He led a team of more than 60 writers and editors, publishing blog posts and articles to promote a tech company that packages and resells data on everything from real estate to used cars. \"It was really engaging work,\" Miller says, a chance to flex his creativity and collaborate with experts on a variety of subjects. But one day, Miller's manager told him about a new project. \"They wanted to use AI to cut down on costs,\" he says. (Miller signed a non-disclosure agreement, and asked the BBC to withhold his and the company's name.)","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"A month later, the business introduced an automated system. Miller's manager would plug a headline for an article into an online form, an AI model would generate an outline based on that title, and Miller would get an alert on his computer. Instead of coming up with their own ideas, his writers would create articles around those outlines, and Miller would do a final edit before the stories were published. Miller only had a few months to adapt before he got news of a second layer of automation. Going forward, ChatGPT would write the articles in their entirety, and most of his team was fired. The few people remaining were left with an even less creative task: editing ChatGPT's subpar text to make it sound more human.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"A month later, the business introduced an automated system. Miller's manager would plug a headline for an article into an online form, an AI model would generate an outline based on that title, and Miller would get an alert on his computer. Instead of coming up with their own ideas, his writers would create articles around those outlines, and Miller would do a final edit before the stories were published. Miller only had a few months to adapt before he got news of a second layer of automation. Going forward, ChatGPT would write the articles in their entirety, and most of his team was fired. The few people remaining were left with an even less creative task: editing ChatGPT's subpar text to make it sound more human.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"By 2024, the company laid off the rest of Miller's team, and he was alone. \"All of a sudden I was just doing everyone's job,\" Miller says. Every day, he'd open the AI-written documents to fix the robot's formulaic mistakes, churning out the work that used to employ dozens of people.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"By 2024, the company laid off the rest of Miller's team, and he was alone. \"All of a sudden I was just doing everyone's job,\" Miller says. Every day, he'd open the AI-written documents to fix the robot's formulaic mistakes, churning out the work that used to employ dozens of people.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"quote","model":{"text":"In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind","quoteSource":"","quoteSourceTitle":""}},{"type":"advertisement","model":{"adType":"horizontal"},"incrementedType":"mid_1"},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"\"Mostly, it was just about cleaning things up and making the writing sound less awkward, cutting out weirdly formal or over-enthusiastic language,\" Miller says. \"It was more editing than I had to do with human writers, but it was always the exact same kinds of edits. The real problem was it was just so repetitive and boring. It started to feel like I was the robot.\"","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"\"Mostly, it was just about cleaning things up and making the writing sound less awkward, cutting out weirdly formal or over-enthusiastic language,\" Miller says. \"It was more editing than I had to do with human writers, but it was always the exact same kinds of edits. The real problem was it was just so repetitive and boring. It started to feel like I was the robot.\"","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Miller's experience reflects a broader shift. In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind. AI is often less expensive than a person, but early adopters are quick to learn it can't always perform on the same level. Now, people like Miller are finding themselves being asked to team up with the same robots that are stealing their jobs to give the algorithms a bit of humanity  a hidden army making AI seem better than it really is.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Miller's experience reflects a broader shift. readabilityObject.title: AI took their jobs. Now they get paid to make it sound human
readabilityObject.content:
If you're worried about how AI will affect your job, the world of copywriters may offer a glimpse of the future.

Writer Benjamin Miller not his real name was thriving in early 2023. He led a team of more than 60 writers and editors, publishing blog posts and articles to promote a tech company that packages and resells data on everything from real estate to used cars. "It was really engaging work," Miller says, a chance to flex his creativity and collaborate with experts on a variety of subjects. But one day, Miller's manager told him about a new project. "They wanted to use AI to cut down on costs," he says. (Miller signed a non-disclosure agreement, and asked the BBC to withhold his and the company's name.)

A month later, the business introduced an automated system. Miller's manager would plug a headline for an article into an online form, an AI model would generate an outline based on that title, and Miller would get an alert on his computer. Instead of coming up with their own ideas, his writers would create articles around those outlines, and Miller would do a final edit before the stories were published. Miller only had a few months to adapt before he got news of a second layer of automation. Going forward, ChatGPT would write the articles in their entirety, and most of his team was fired. The few people remaining were left with an even less creative task: editing ChatGPT's subpar text to make it sound more human.

By 2024, the company laid off the rest of Miller's team, and he was alone. "All of a sudden I was just doing everyone's job," Miller says. Every day, he'd open the AI-written documents to fix the robot's formulaic mistakes, churning out the work that used to employ dozens of people.

In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind

"Mostly, it was just about cleaning things up and making the writing sound less awkward, cutting out weirdly formal or over-enthusiastic language," Miller says. "It was more editing than I had to do with human writers, but it was always the exact same kinds of edits. The real problem was it was just so repetitive and boring. It started to feel like I was the robot."

Miller's experience reflects a broader shift. In numerous industries, AI is being used to produce work that was once the exclusive domain of the human mind. AI is often less expensive than a person, but early adopters are quick to learn it can't always perform on the same level. Now, people like Miller are finding themselves being asked to team up with the same robots that are stealing their jobs to give the algorithms a bit of humanity a hidden army making AI seem better than it really is.

If AI gets dramatically more effective, this will be a temporary solution. If it doesn't, Miller's story could be a preview of what's coming to other professions.

But on a much smaller scale, some workers already face distressing consequences. If there's one thing the large language models powered by generative AI can do, it's string together words and paragraphs, putting some writers on the frontline.

We're adding the 'human touch', but that often requires a deep, developmental edit on a piece of writing Catrina Cowart

The impact is already being felt among copywriters the people who write marketing material and other content for businesses. In some corners of the copywriting business, AI is a blessing. It can be a useful tool that speeds up work and enhances creativity. But other copywriters, especially those early in their careers, say AI is making it harder to find jobs.

But some have also noticed a new type of gig is emerging, one that pays a lot less: fixing the robots' shoddy writing.

"We're adding the human touch, but that often requires a deep, developmental edit on a piece of writing," says Catrina Cowart, a copywriter based in Lexington, Kentucky, US, who's done work editing AI text."The grammar and word choice just sound weird. You're always cutting out flowery words like 'therefore' and 'nevertheless' that don't fit in casual writing. Plus, you have to fact-check the whole thing because AI just makes things up, which takes forever because it's not just big ideas. AI hallucinates these flippant little things in throwaway lines that you'd never notice."

Cowart says the AI-humanising often takes longer than writing a piece from scratch, but the pay is worse. "On the job platforms where you find this work, it usually maxes out around 10 cents (0.08) a word. But that's when you're writing, This is considered an editing job, so typically you're only getting one to five cents (0.008-0.04) a word," she says.

"It's tedious, horrible work, and they pay you next to nothing for it," Cowart says.

Other industries have seen similar examples of lower-paid human beings quietly powering the machines, from stepping in to help with automated ordering systems to labelling the images used to train AI vision systems in the first place.

It's been an incredible co-creative partner Rebecca Dugas

But for some in the copywriting world, whether the arrival of AI is a good or bad thing depends on how people approach it, and how far along people are in their careers. Some writers say working the tools into their creative process can even improve their work.

The American Writers and Artists Institute (AWAI), an organisation that offers training and resources for freelance writers, hosts a variety of courses on artificial intelligence for its members. AWAI president Rebecca Matter says AI classes are now the institute's most popular offering by far. "It's an incredible tool," Matter says. "For people who make copywriting a career, the risk isn't AI taking their jobs, it's that they have to adapt. That can be uncomfortable, but I think it's a huge opportunity."

Matter says the transition to the AI world has been smooth for most of the writers she knows. In fact, it's become such an inherent part of the copywriting process that many writers now add personal "AI policies" to their professional websites to explain how they use the technology.

Rebecca Dugas, a copywriter with nine years of experience, says AI has been a "godsend" that lets her turn out the same high-quality work in a fraction of the time.

"I use AI whenever my clients are comfortable with it," she says. "Whether it's brainstorming, market research, reworking paragraphs when I'm banging my head against the wall, it's been an incredible co-creative partner."

But Dugas understands that clients may have reservations about the technology. Her own AI policy explains that Dugas is happy to forgo AI for those who prefer it but you can expect to pay more. The extra time and mental energy required means her AI-free projects come with a higher price tag.

As AI gets better, Dugas expects that some businesses will turn to ChatGPT and other tools for their writing needs instead of hiring human beings. "But I think even now we're getting to the point where companies are realising that if you don't understand copywriting, you can't judge the effectiveness of what the AI produces," she says. According to Dugas, that means there will always be well-paying work for talented, established writers.

Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptly

But copywriters on the lower end of the career spectrum may not be so lucky. Today, many in that position find themselves in the middle of a distinctly modern set of contradictions.

A great deal of copywriting work comes from website owners who want articles that will generate more traffic from Google. However, Google made a number of dramatic announcements in the last year about its effort to remove "unhelpful" content from search results. That sparked fears that the tech giant may penalise websites that host AI-generated content.  Google maintains that AI-writing is fine if the content is high quality, but these reassurances haven't dissuaded concerns.

According to Cowart, many of the same freelance writing platforms that have AI detection software in place are simultaneously hiring people to edit content produced by chatbots. That means in some corners of the copywriting ecosystem, almost everything revolves around efforts to avoid the appearance of artificial intelligence.

"They're selling AI content and paying you to fix it, and at the same time they're sending you emails about how to write like a human so you don't trigger their AI detector," Cowart says. "It's so insulting." Worse, the detectors are regularly updated to keep up with ongoing changes from the companies who make AI chatbots, which means the rules about what might get your writing flagged as AI constantly shift. "It's frustrating, because there are a million ways to say the same thing in English, but which one is more human? I don't like the guessing," she says.

Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptly. After months of repetitive editing work, He got called in to an unexpected meeting. On 5 April 2024, the same day a historic earthquake shook his hometown of New York, he was laid off. The company decided that Miller was just another unnecessary layer of human intervention.

"I more or less got automated out of a job," Miller says.

You might also like:

Fortunately, it wasn't long before Miller found a new, if rather ironic, opportunity. He got a job at Undetectable AI, a technology company that builds software to make AI writing harder to identify. In other words, Miller is helping a company that's using AI to do the work he was forced into after AI took his job in the first place.

Bars Juhasz, chief technology officer of Undetectable AI, says tools like the ones his company produces are certain to have some negative effects on the labour market, but he's optimistic about the future of work. "When the automobile was first introduced in an era of horses and carts, people reacted like this was the end of days. But society always adapts," Juhasz says. "I think we're going to see a lot of jobs being replaced, and freelancers will be the hardest hit. I do feel for them. But these people who are getting paid to humanise AI are fantastic opportunists. Sure, it's not a great job, but they have effectively recognised a new seat at a moment when we're redefining the idea of productivity. People who can learn to work with the technology are going to be OK."

Miller doesn't look back fondly on his time in the AI-humanisation mines. "I contributed to a lot of the garbage that's filling the internet and destroying it," he says. "Nobody was even reading this stuff by the time I left because it's just trash." Ultimately, Miller assumes the company will just take down the AI articles he worked on. "It'll be like it never even happened."

--

For more technology news and insights, sign up to our Tech Decoded newsletter, while The Essential List delivers a handpicked selection of features and insights to your inbox twice a week.

In some corners of the copywriting business, AI is a blessing. It can be a useful tool that speeds up work and enhances creativity. But other copywriters, especially those early in their careers, say AI is making it harder to find jobs.But some have also noticed a new type of gig is emerging, one that pays a lot less: fixing the robots' shoddy writing."We're adding the human touch, but that often requires a deep, developmental edit on a piece of writing," says Catrina Cowart, a copywriter based in Lexington, Kentucky, US, who's done work editing AI text."The grammar and word choice just sound weird. You're always cutting out flowery words like 'therefore' and 'nevertheless' that don't fit in casual writing. Plus, you have to fact-check the whole thing because AI just makes things up, which takes forever because it's not just big ideas. AI hallucinates these flippant little things in throwaway lines that you'd never notice."Cowart says the AI-humanising often takes longer than writing a piece from scratch, but the pay is worse. "On the job platforms where you find this work, it usually maxes out around 10 cents (0.08) a word. But that's when you're writing, This is considered an editing job, so typically you're only getting one to five cents (0.008-0.04) a word," she says."It's tedious, horrible work, and they pay you next to nothing for it," Cowart says.Other industries have seen similar examples oflower-paid human beings quietly powering the machines, from stepping in to help with automated ordering systems to labelling the images used to train AI vision systems in the first place.It's been an incredible co-creative partner  Rebecca DugasBut for some in the copywriting world, whether the arrival of AI is a good or bad thing depends on how people approach it, and how far along people are in their careers. Some writers say working the tools into their creative process can even improve their work.The American Writers and Artists Institute (AWAI), an organisation that offers training and resources for freelance writers, hosts a variety of courses on artificial intelligence for its members. AWAI president Rebecca Matter says AI classes are now the institute's most popular offering by far. "It's an incredible tool," Matter says. "For people who make copywriting a career, the risk isn't AI taking their jobs, it's that they have to adapt. That can be uncomfortable, but I think it's a huge opportunity."Matter says the transition to the AI world has been smooth for most of the writers she knows. In fact, it's become such an inherent part of the copywriting process that many writers now add personal "AI policies" to their professional websites to explain how they use the technology.Rebecca Dugas, a copywriter with nine years of experience, says AI has been a "godsend" that lets her turn out the same high-quality work in a fraction of the time."I use AI whenever my clients are comfortable with it," she says. "Whether it's brainstorming, market research, reworking paragraphs when I'm banging my head against the wall, it's been an incredible co-creative partner."AI makes life easier for some writers, but for others, it adds insult to injury (Serenity Strull/BBC/Getty Images)But Dugas understands that clients may have reservations about the technology. Her own AI policy explains that Dugas is happy to forgo AI for those who prefer it  but you can expect to pay more. The extra time and mental energy required means her AI-free projects come with a higher price tag.As AI gets better, Dugas expects that some businesses will turn to ChatGPT and other tools for their writing needs instead of hiring human beings. "But I think even now we're getting to the point where companies are realising that if you don't understand copywriting, you can't judge the effectiveness of what the AI produces," she says. According to Dugas, that means there will always be well-paying work for talented, established writers.Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptlyBut copywriters on the lower end of the career spectrum may not be so lucky. Today, many in that position find themselves in the middle of a distinctly modern set of contradictions.A great deal of copywriting work comes from website owners who want articles that will generate more traffic from Google. However, Google made a number of dramatic announcements in the last year about its effort to remove "unhelpful" content from search results. That sparked fears that the tech giant may penalise websites that host AI-generated content. Google maintains that AI-writing is fine if the content is high quality, but these reassurances haven't dissuaded concerns.According to Cowart, many of the same freelance writing platforms that have AI detection software in place are simultaneously hiring people to edit content produced by chatbots. That means in some corners of the copywriting ecosystem, almost everything revolves around efforts to avoid the appearance of artificial intelligence."They're selling AI content and paying you to fix it, and at the same time they're sending you emails about how to write like a human so you don't trigger their AI detector," Cowart says. "It's so insulting." Worse, the detectors are regularly updated to keep up with ongoing changes from the companies who make AI chatbots, which means the rules about what might get your writing flagged as AI constantly shift. "It's frustrating, because there are a million ways to say the same thing in English, but which one is more human? I don't like the guessing," she says.Miller's time humanising AI ended abruptly. After months of repetitive editing work, He got called in to an unexpected meeting. On 5 April 2024, the same day a historic earthquake shook his hometown of New York, he was laid off. The company decided that Miller was just another unnecessary layer of human intervention."I more or less got automated out of a job," Miller says.You might also like:Fortunately, it wasn't long before Miller found a new, if rather ironic, opportunity. He got a job at Undetectable AI, a technology company that builds software to make AI writing harder to identify. In other words, Miller is helping a company that's using AI to do the work he was forced into after AI took his job in the first place.Bars Juhasz, chief technology officer of Undetectable AI, says tools like the ones his company produces are certain to have some negative effects on the labour market, but he's optimistic about the future of work. "When the automobile was first introduced in an era of horses and carts, people reacted like this was the end of days. But society always adapts," Juhasz says. "I think we're going to see a lot of jobs being replaced, and freelancers will be the hardest hit. I do feel for them. But these people who are getting paid to humanise AI are fantastic opportunists. Sure, it's not a great job, but they have effectively recognised a new seat at a moment when we're redefining the idea of productivity. People who can learn to work with the technology are going to be OK."Miller doesn't look back fondly on his time in the AI-humanisation mines. "I contributed to a lot of the garbage that's filling the internet and destroying it," he says. "Nobody was even reading this stuff by the time I left because it's just trash." Ultimately, Miller assumes the company will just take down the AI articles he worked on. "It'll be like it never even happened."--For more technology news and insights, sign up to our Tech Decoded newsletter, while The Essential List delivers a handpicked selection of features and insights to your inbox twice a week.
